Engineer colleagues! We have a great job opportunity in the Planning Department!
City of Overland Park
City of Overland Park
7,117 followers
7,117 followers
Private development. Public impact.

We’re hiring a Supervisory Civil Engineer to lead a team that reviews private development plans and inspects infrastructure projects across the city.

From floodplain management to final plats, you’ll play a key role in ensuring our community grows responsibly and sustainably. This leadership role works closely with developers, residents, staff and elected officials to support safe, efficient development.

Learn more and apply now at http://bit.ly/4ffsml3.

I am a Professor of the Practice in the Environmental Assessment Professional Science Masters and the undergraduate Environmental Studies degree completion programs where I teach undergraduate and graduate students and mentor students in capstone projects. I also conduct applied research and outreach in community and climate resilience, environmental conservation and policy.

Heartland Conservation Alliance
Heartland Conservation Alliance
Jan 2012 - Present · 13 yrs 10 mos
Jan 2012 to Present · 13 yrs 10 mos
Kansas City, Missouri Area
Kansas City, Missouri Area
Founding President of Heartland Conservation Alliance, served in this capacity until March 2016. During this period HCA grew from an all-volunteer organization to an established conservation alliance serving and collaborating with numerous federal, state, local, and not-for-profit organizations; with an annual operating budget of over $300,000, three full-time and part-time staff, and an AmeriCorps VISTA. Currently serving on the Board of Directors supporting the Conservation Work Group and Policy Work Group, the Urban Waters Federal Partnership, and ecosystem restoration at the Kansas City, Missouri Municipal Farm near the confluence of Brush Creek and the Blue River.

Lake Lenexa
Lake Lenexa
Apr 2001 - Aug 2008
Apr 2001 - Aug 2008
Show project
Lake Lenexa is a (~30 acre) man-made lake in western Lenexa KS. The dam and spillway feature unique design elements, including a contoured ogee spillway and 360 degree accessibility via a bridge spanning the spillway stilling basin. Black Hoof park is adjacent to the lake, and features multiple wetland areas, including an educational boardwalk.

The dam and spillway feature unique design elements, including a contoured ogee spillway and 360 degree accessibility via a bridge spanning the spillway stilling basin. Heartland 2050
Heartland 2050
Show project
By 2050 the population in the Omaha/Council Bluffs region is projected to nearly double. When it’s compared to regions across the country, it's in an enviable position because its quality of life is high and backed by strong neighborhoods, a solid economy, and low cost of living. Still, the region faces serious socio-economic disparities (areas of concentrated poverty and housing segregation) and challenges (projected major demographic shifts) that will test the region’s resiliency. Community leaders in the public, private, and nonprofit sectors are already taking steps through Heartland 2050, the Omaha/Council Bluff’s region’s first regional vision plan, to connect its more vulnerable communities to educational and economic opportunities. Residents want to ensure that the region continues to thrive and becomes a place where people of all walks of life have the opportunity to live, work, play and contribute.
